title: My wife received a summons from a credit card company. Can she file bankruptsy without including me? What options do we have?
question: This acoount is in her name only. She tried making payment arrangement with this CC company before but they would not work with her, so she had to stop paying it. She has many other accounts she is paying, but it getting very difficult. My credit is excellent, therefore we own a house and car in my name (two other cars are in both of our names).
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Bankruptcy petition,Bankruptcy documents,Bankruptcy exemptions,Bankruptcy homestead exemption,Credit,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Hearsay in criminal cases,Lawsuits and disputes,Filing a lawsuit,Summons and complaint,Spousal debt,Sued for debt,Marriage
answers:
She can file BK separately. However, BK should only be your last option. If the suit was filed by a "debt buyer", not by the original creditor, it may be feasible to effectively defend the suit. The plaintiff has the obligation of not only bringing a lawyer to court but to also bring competent witnesses, with personal knowledge (not hearsay), to prove their case. Debt buyer often have limited access to witnesses employed by the original creditor.

In addition, do you understand that a civil judgment is only an authorization for the creditor to try to levy upon non-exempt assets of the debtor. It is not an order requiring the debtor to pay. California law provides for many exemptions, which include the homestead exemption, government benefits, income required to pay for "necessities of life", a vehicle up to a certain value (of equity), household goods, etc., etc. These are the same exemptions that would be allowed in a Chapter 7 BK filing.

My advise is to meet with an attorney who is experienced in litigating against collection agencies and credit card companies, and pay for a one hour consultation.

Before limiting yourself to filing bankruptcy for one debt collection lawsuit, I'd recommend exploring and considering all available options, including discussing this with an experienced debt collection defense attorney, who will elaborate on the particular situation and potential outcomes. In fact, bankruptcy can be a back up plan, "Plan B." The first video on the home page of my web site reviews all options when served with a debt collection lawsuit. Also, my law blog has many postings that discuss this even further. A debt collection lawsuits do automatically mean that the result will be a judgment. There are also many settlement options that can be explored.

Have you/your wife tried settling this debt with the law firm that is on the summons and complaint? Have either of you spoken with a debt collection consumer attorney? I have linked to two of my law blog postings on your next steps and possible outcomes, below.

A couple that is married isn't required to file bankruptcy together and unless they have joint credit accounts, the bankruptcy of one isn't likely to affect the credit of the other. Whether your spouse will be placing any community personal property at risk will depend on the exemptions she is eligible to claim and does properly claim in her bankruptcy. An experienced bankruptcy lawyer will know these exemptions like the back of their hand. The fact that property is in your name alone doesn't necessarily mean that your wife won't have to disclose and exempt this property in her bankruptcy though.

I am also concerned whenever someone files a bankruptcy over just one debt. Not every debt is eligible to be discharged in a bankruptcy and your Wife must also qualify to file bankruptcy. Since this matter has gone into litigation, it might be more prudent to retain an attorney to settle the suit. The devil is in the details. I would be meeting with a local attorney to review this suit early next week and you can use the "find a lawyer" search tool here on Avvo to help you.

Yes, one half of a married couple can petition for bankruptcy protection independently of the spouse. Whether that strategy will meet the objectives of the filer without unnecessarily involving the spouse is a more complicated question. Nothing short of very focused advice of an experienced bankruptcy attorney after a full case review will meet the needs of your wife, and yourself. If you do not know such a lawyer, use the attorney-finder at www.nacba.org.

Best wishes for an outcome you can accept, and please remember to designate a best answer.
